> 
>    From: Shane Celis <shane@...>
> Many times over JUnit seems to be employed for 
> functional/acceptance/integration testing (usually somewhat 
> awkwardly).  
> Are there any testing approaches or frameworks that can be 
> suggested for 
> this sort of testing?  Because many of the methodologies 
> suggested for 
> unit testing aren't applicable to this sort of testing.  Have 
> the xUnit 
> people, or anyone else for that matter, addressed this problem space?


Hi,

I am currently co-writing a practitioners report submission for the XP2002
conference about our[*] experiences with acceptance testing. We've got a
testing framework that's not based on JUnit at all, and we think it's
working very well.

We force the application to operate in batch mode while we acceptance test
it, provide input from file/standard input redirects, and collect all output
as text files. We then have the full power of unix text processing commands
(ie diff) to analyse and compare the output to previous runs. Basically, if
the output is different, the test fails.

The testing framework takes responsibility for version controlling input and
output for each test case, and running the application executable with said
input, and checking the output for differences (ie failures). The test cases
run in parallel over a network, using some third party load balancing
software.

The main advantages of this approach are that you're not writing any code to
add a new test case, only supplying new input data and recording a standard
result. Secondly the tests run in parallel instead of in series, so if the
load on your network is low, you get results faster, and often all the
results in the time it takes the slowest test to run. 

The disadvantages are that you have to force your app to work in batch mode
and produce text output, which may or may not be straightforward. 

Hope that might give you some ideas for acceptance testing.

Emily

[*] the XP team at Carmen Systems, which I am not actually a member of, but
I know a lot about.
